Authors: Bond, Gary R.; Drake, Robert E.
Article Title: Making the Case for IPS Supported Employment
Abstract: Individual Placement and Support (IPS) is an evidence-based practice for helping people with severe mental illness (SMI) gain competitive employment, yet those who could benefit often find it difficult to obtain IPS services. We summarize the evidence supporting the effectiveness of IPS and the benefits of working, discuss the barriers to implementing IPS in the U.S., and suggest policy changes that could expand its access.

llama-3.2-3b-instruct.reason: The study design lacks a rigorous evaluation and no control group.

qwen2.5-7b-instruct-1m.reason: The study design is not a meta-analysis, systematic review of controlled trials, RCT, cluster RCT, or quasi-experimental study with a control group. It lacks rigorous evaluation and does not include a control group.

phi-3-mini-4k-instruct.reason: The study focuses on policy advocacy and barriers to implementing IPS rather than evaluating the effectiveness of IPS interventions in improving employment outcomes for people with mental health disorders.

mistral-small-24b-instruct-2501.reason: Meets all inclusion criteria: quasi-experimental study design, conducted in the US, published within the timeframe, focuses on supported employment for people with mental health disorders, and includes employment outcomes.
